summary: This is a Law360 news article covering U.S. Secretary of Labor Alex Acosta's testimony before the House Committee on Education and Labor on May 1, 2019. Acosta defended his role in the 2008 non-prosecution agreement with Jeffrey Epstein, pushed back against Democratic lawmakers' criticism linking it to his enforcement of labor laws, and discussed various regulatory initiatives including overtime rules and a new fiduciary rule.

persons.name: Alex Acosta
persons.context: Defended his handling of the Jeffrey Epstein non-prosecution agreement from a decade prior when he was U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida, and testified on various Department of Labor regulatory matters.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Millionaire who received a non-prosecution agreement in a teen sex trafficking case from Acosta's office about a decade earlier, pleading guilty to lesser state charges.

persons.name: Kenneth A. Marra
persons.context: Found in February 2019 that Acosta and other prosecutors violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act by misleading Epstein's victims about the non-prosecution agreement.

persons.name: Frederica Wilson
persons.context: Expressed concern during the hearing that Acosta's alleged mishandling of the Epstein case indicated he wouldn't adequately protect workers' interests.

persons.name: Virginia Foxx
persons.context: Top Republican on the committee who expressed concern about the status of the Obama-era overtime regulation and sought assurances on the timing of the replacement rule.

persons.name: Mark Takano
persons.context: Questioned Acosta about the overtime rule, leading Acosta to defend the DOL's decision to appeal a ruling that blocked the Obama administration's version.

persons.name: Bobby Scott
persons.context: Asked Acosta about the minimum wage, to which Acosta responded that the Trump administration did not support a change to the federal minimum wage at that time.

connections.description: Acosta, as U.S. Attorney, struck a non-prosecution agreement with Epstein regarding teen sex trafficking charges.
Judge Marra ruled that Acosta and other prosecutors violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act in the Epstein case.
Wilson criticized Acosta's handling of the Epstein case during the committee hearing, suggesting it reflected on his approach to labor enforcement.

events.title: House Labor Committee Hearing
events.description: U.S. Secretary of Labor Alex Acosta testified before the House Committee on Education and Labor, defending his role in the Epstein plea deal and discussing DOL regulatory initiatives.

events.title: Epstein Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: As U.S. Attorney, Alex Acosta struck a non-prosecution agreement with Jeffrey Epstein, allowing him to plead guilty to lesser state charges and averting federal prosecution for himself and alleged co-conspirators.

events.title: Judge Marra's Ruling on CVRA Violation
events.description: U.S. District Judge Kenneth A. Marra found that Acosta and other prosecutors violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act by misleading Epstein's victims about the non-prosecution agreement.

keyFacts: Alex Acosta defended the 2008 non-prosecution agreement with Jeffrey Epstein, stating the DOJ's position was that the Crime Victims' Rights Act was not violated, despite a federal judge's February 2019 ruling to the contrary.
The non-prosecution agreement averted potential federal charges not only against Epstein but also against alleged co-conspirators in the teen sex trafficking case.
Democratic lawmakers, including Rep. Frederica Wilson, linked Acosta's handling of the Epstein case to concerns about his enforcement of worker protection laws.
Acosta testified that the Epstein case was appealed 'all the way up to the deputy attorney general's office' because of contentions the prosecution was 'too aggressive,' not for being insufficient.
The hearing also covered non-Epstein DOL matters, including overtime rules, a new fiduciary rule being developed with the SEC, the Janus decision, and the federal minimum wage.
